On Wed, 16 August, 2006 6:06 pm, Joel G. Altman wrote:
> I've been dragging the programmers on my latest project into unit
> testing, and they have not all gone quietly.
>
> One senior developer to whom I gave the task of developing the graphical
> portion of the user interface says there is no way to use JUnit on his
> code.  I believe it can be done, but I haven't found anything in JUnit
> Recipes I can use to convince him.
>
> Can somebody give me ammunition for this task?  What would be the best
> method for unit testing graphics code?

Robert C.  Martin wrote an article in IEEE Software magazine last year
called "The Test Bus Imperative: Architectures That Support Automated
Acceptance Testing". This article contains a lot of good insights on how
to approach the problem of automated testing of GUIs. You can find the
article at http://doi.ieeecomputersociety.org/10.1109/MS.2005.110 - though
you need to have membership to the IEEE Computer Society to view the
thing, or pay $20

To summarise the main point of the article, strive to ensure that *all*
logic in your software has a testable interface (aka test bus). The GUI
becomes a very thin shell over testable presentation logic, which hooks
into lower level business logic, and so on (all of which is testable).

Good luck!
